summary.seg: This composite manuscript consists of five parts that were probably produced separately from each other. While the first and last parts (f. i and ff. 101a-101bis) are fragments from other manuscripts, the three parts in between them (Part 1: ff. 1-52*; Part 2: ff. 53-[96a]; Part 3: ff. 97-101) all contain legal texts that were all or largely copied by Walter Atwell (fl. c. 1520) of the Staple Inn. While the material aspects and layouts of these three parts suggest that they were initially produced by Atwell as separate units, a table of contents that Atwell added to describe the manuscript as whole on f. 101v leaves no doubt that he joined the three parts together during his lifetime.

This manuscript also contains a number of medical recipes and texts added in Atwell’s hand. Among these are Latin texts that are attributed to the Oxford physician John Cokkys [Cokkes] (d. by 1475) but have not been studied before as part of the corpus of his surviving works. The manuscript features a medical mnemonic on strangury, diarrhea, and dysentery (f. 52v) attributed to Cokkes and an apothecary recipe for purging the humors that is attributed to Magistrum Johannes Cokkes.

It had also gone unnoticed until now that Atwell added the very same mnemonic and apothecary recipe attributed to John Cokkys to London, British Library, Harley MS 5144f. 1v (per Magistrum J Cokkys), another volume with legal texts (Year Book for the reigns of Henry IV and Henry V).

These discoveries add to the known corpus of Atwell's medical works, which was principally known to consist of a number of Middle English recipes in Oxford, Bodleian Library, Ashmole MS 1432 and medical lectures in Cambridge, King’s College, MS 16 (for a short biograpy of Cokkys, see Talbot and Hammond (1965), pp. 134-136).

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: ff. i, 26, 27, and 52* are parchment leaves; ff. 1-25, 28-52, 53-101a are paper leaves

foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
ff. 31bis, 52*, and 101a-101bis have been foliated in pencil by a 20th-century hand.
ff. 101a-101bis are two parts of a single folded leaf.

supportDesc.foliation: ff. 62-94 are numbered in Roman numerals 'i'-'xxxii' by a 16th-century hand.

collation.formula: singleton (f. i)| 152+1: 1 small leaf added to 31 (f. 31bis) + 1 singleton (f. 52*) | 244+1: 1 small leaf attached to 44 (f. [96a]) | 36-1: 5 is missing | singleton (ff. 101a-101bis)

signatures.p: Modern quire numbers in pencil added to the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires.

binding.p: Brown half leather binding with marbled paper sides and vellum corners; binding made by Gray, Cambridge, in 1955 (see the stamp and inscription on the inside of the upper cover.

provenance.p: Walter Atwell (fl. c. 1520), member of the Staple Inn Atwell, Walter, fl. c. 1520, member of the Staple Inn: compiled and owned the manuscript as indicated by the occurence of his name in ownership inscriptions and colophons throughout the manuscript: Ihu mercy Lady help quod Walterus Atwell cujus anime propitietur (f. 28r); Jhesu mercy lady help Quod Walterus Atwell cujus anime propitietur Deus (f. 29r); Atwell Walterus [in red ink] (f. 38r); Finis laudetur deus quod Walterus Atwell (f. 41r); Llewta retaw [his name written in reverse] (f. 52* recto); Atwell Waltero constat liber iste benigno (f. 52* verso); Deo gracias quod Walterus Atwell artis Bacularius cuius anime propicietur deus amen Jhesus - Anno viijo h viij xxiij die julij finitur istud reporte in scriptis per me W.A. predictum etcaetera (f. 49v); Jhesus nazarenus rex judeorum crucifixus fili dei vnu miserere nobis quod Walter Atwell (f. 49v); Finis deo gracias quod Walterus Atwell (f. 58v); Finis deo gracias Walterus Atwell (f. 60v); Finis laudetur deus quod Walterus Atwell cuius anime propicietur Deus amen Jhesus Jhesus Jhesus esto mihi Jhesus Amen (f. 95r); Finis hujus capituli quod Walterus Atwell (f. 96r).

John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : probably no. 330 (this number also inscribed on f. i recto) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697), where the volume is described as Matters relating to our Laws in the times of Edward II ... Edward VI (identified in MS Oo.7.54).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : but without the usual donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by John Baker and Jayne Ringrose, Catalogue of English Legal Manuscripts in Cambridge University Library (1996) (used here by kind permission of the Boydell Press); and M. Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), Index of Middle English Prose, 19 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Early treatises on the practice of the justices of the peace in the fifteenth and sixteenth century / by B.H. Putnam.

series.title: Oxford studies in social and legal history

monogr.title: The medical practitioners in medieval England : a biographical register
The Oxford History of the Laws of England. Volume VI, 1483-1558
Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo)

analytic.title: Glanvill after Glanvill: The afterlife of a Medieval Legal Treatise

series.title: Medieval Law and Its Practice: Studies in Medieval Legal History in Honour of Paul Brand

analytic.title: Magna Carta in The Inns of Court 1340–1540

series.title: Cambridge Studies in English Legal History

monogr.title: A Critical Companion to John Skelton

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.5.18, ff. i recto-i verso

msItem.title: Alphabetical table of contents of a legal work (not present)
msItem.textLang: Latin heading with French chapter titles
msItem.rubric: i recto Capitula istius libri pout patet subsequentur
msItem.incipit: i recto Accompt
msItem.explicit: i verso Varem et Wythernam foo 404

msItem.title: Note
msItem.note: A dictum per Magistrum Askett anno vi. H. viii. in quaresme, referring to Richard Hesketh (d. 1520?) in Gray's Inn, Lent 1515 in the hand of Walter Atwell.

p.seg: No ruling. Three columns. About 58 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant form of decoration.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 15th or early 16th century

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.5.18, ff. 1-52*

msItem.title: Table of the years of the reigns of English kings covered in a work (not present)
msItem.rubric: 1r In isto libro to continentur anni in primis de Edwardo secundo
msItem.note: The table apparently belonged to a large collection of year books, covering a large period from the 1st year of the reign of Edward II (1307/8) until the 31st year of the reign of King Henry VI (1452/3).

msItem.title: Medical recipe for healing the eyes
msItem.incipit: 1r Take ij or iij handfull and breke theym or kytt theym lyke wores comyn j li or j quartes on and boyle theym in vynegre with crommes of broune bred in to þe thyknes of a plaster and then ley hit vpon a pece of blankett and ley hit to the hede and vpon both the eyon after as hit nedith. Also take þe gall of a bole or of a noxe and bete it vnto þe flemne be clene away and all clarified and anoynte thymne eyon aboue and beneth so þat nothyng come in þi eyen
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Report of Bower v Chesman
msItem.note: The report is dated to Tr. xxo H. vii.

msItem.title: Indenture between Thomas Gerarde and Humphrey Stanley, dated 1 Richard III
msItem.textLang: English indenture with a notarial attestation in Latin
msItem.rubric: 2r Ann Endenture of Mariage
msItem.incipit: 2r Thys Indenture made þe xxti day of ffebruary þe first yer of þe reign of King Richarde þe thyrde betwix Sir Thomas Gerarde knyght opon þat on parte and Humfrey Stanley squier opon þat other parte
msItem.explicit: 2v This Indenture made the xxti day of februarye etcaetera vt prius est

msItem.title: Abbreviamentum quorundam casuum [title from table of contents on f. 101v]
msItem.textLang: French cases with an English rubric
msItem.rubric: 4rIhesus mercy lady help - Accompt
msItem.note: Copy of the beginning of an alphabetical abridgement of year-book cases. The cases have the titles Accompt and Age. The latest cases included date to 27 Henry VI. The text ends imperfectly.

msItem.title: Anonymous reading on the Statue of Merton, cc. 1-2
msItem.textLang: French text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 18v In nomine patris filii et spiritus sancti Amen - Merton capitulo primo
msItem.incipit: 18v" De viduis que post mortem virorum suorum expelluntur de Dotibus - Nota que cest estatute done que la feme recovera damages
msItem.note: There is an internal reference on f. 19r to Magister Litelton en ses tenures which probably fixes the date after 1481 (see Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.11.60).

msItem.title: Assizes
msItem.textLang: French notes with an English heading
msItem.rubric: 19v Wrytte patent and a plaint with a retourne
msItem.note: With a marginal reference to Westminster II. Perhaps taken from an abridgment of the book of assizes with cases up to King Henry VI. At the top of f. 20v there is a reference to the item on ff. 41v-49v: Vide en le Report de old Spylman puis en cest lyver sur lestatue W. ijd capitulo xxv. Spylman refers to John Spelman (d. 1545), bencher of Gray's Inn.

msItem.title: Reading by Morgan Kydwelly (d. 1505) on Magna Carta, c. 11, treating of the various courts and their jurisdiction
msItem.rubric: 26r Magna Carta. Lectura M. K. tempore qudragesimale anno reegni regis Edwardi iiiiti xxiido in interiori templo etcaetera Communia placita non sequantur Cur nostram sed teneantur in aliquo loco cetero etcaetera
msItem.finalRubric: 41r Lex ordinatur propter transgressores. Finis laudetur deus quod Walterus Atwell
msItem.note: Begins with a table of four weeks' lectures (beginning: Prima septimana. Curia parliamenti); the first lecture begins: Acte de parlement: En lescheker chambre Fortescue rehersa coment all parlmement

The reader may be identified from cross-references on ff. 43v-44v as Morgan Kydwelly (d. 1505), who was a governor of the Inner Temple in 1486 and attorney-general 1483-85. The probable date of the reading is 1482-1383.

The text contains various marginal annotations by Atwell, including: Vide report de Fitzherberd de Grays in pur beale plede [...] ove Magister Goldylham (f. 32v), referring to the reading by Anthony Fitzherbert (d. 1539) on the Statue of Marlborough, c. 11, in Gray's in c. 1510, apparently in a text belonging to Fitzherbert and Goldingham; bon mater pur courtz en lez novels abryggementes dez termez (f. 33v), probably a reference to Anthony Fitherbert's La Graunde Abridgement , published c. 1514-16; Memorandum my cramp ryng ove Golsmyth (f. 34v); Memorandum xiio H. vii [...] en lyver A.F. (f. 37v), another reference to Fitzherbert; Vide le lecture de Marow [...] (f. 39r), a reference to the item on ff. 62r-95r; for further details on Fitzherbert and Goldingham see Baker and Ringrose (1996), pp. 209-210.

msItem.title: Extract from the Parliament Rolls, 14 Richard II
msItem.rubric: 31bis verso Ex rotule parliamenti de Anno xiijo Ricardi ijdi
msItem.note: This leaf has been inserted later and contains a text by a different hand, writing in a Secretary script; it may have been added by Walter Atwell to supplement the Reading on Magna Carta on ff. 26r-41r.

msItem.title: Reading of Henry Spelman (d. 1496) in Gay's Inn before 1458 on the Statute of Westminster II, c. 25
msItem.textLang: French text with a Latin headng
msItem.rubric: 41v Westmonasterium secundum capitulo xxvto
msItem.incipit: 41v Vide et nota que en assise de novel disseisin ne gist essone ne protection
msItem.finalRubric: 49v Deo gracias quod Walterus Atwell artis bacularius cujus anime propicietur deus Amen Jhesus. Anno vii o H. xiii. xxiii die Julii finitur istud reporte in scriptis per me W. A. predictum etcaetera Jhesus Nazarenus Rex Judeorum crucifixus fili dei [...] miserere nobis quod Walterus Atwell. Quod Walterus Walterus [sic] Atwell et Margeria uxor ejus
msItem.note: The reading is that of Henry Spelman (d. 1496) on Westminster, chapter 25, in Gay's Inn before 1458 as indicated by a cross-reference on f. 20v. Another copy is extant in MS Hh.2.6 which has been edited and translated in Selden Society 71:1-37 [where c. 1452 is suggested as a date for the reading]. For further details, see Baker and Ringrose (1996), p. 210.

msItem.title: A fragment of an anonymous reading on Westminster II, c. 12
msItem.rubric: 50r W. iide capitulo xii
msItem.incipit: 50r Quia multi per maliciam etcaetera. Ore est avoier ou le defendant recovera damages en appell et ou nemi

msItem.title: Copy of the entry of a traverse in Chancery to an office found on 2 October 1505 at Bramston, Lincolnshire, after the death of Thomas Pynchebek
msItem.rubric: 50v Termino Pasche Anno H. vj xxi
msItem.incipit: 50v Corruptum est per quandam inquisicionem
msItem.note: The traverse was taken on 26 May 1506 by the duchess of Norfolk.

msItem.title: List of the charges used in courts of baron
msItem.textLang: French text with Latin in rubrics
msItem.rubric: 51v Sanctus deus - Ceux sont lez enguerre en court de baron
msItem.incipit: 51v Vous devez enquerrer si ascun tenant franc ou bonde soit devie
msItem.explicit: 51v et loialement fact son office come il [...] faire ou non etcaetera

msItem.title: Copy of the entry of an action of quare impedit by William Cowderey against Morgan Kydwelly and John Atwell, his chaplain, for the advowson of the church of Langton, Dorset; with a plea of ne disturba pas
msItem.rubric: 52r De Termino sancti Michaelis Anno rr h vij promximo R. CCCxlij
msItem.incipit: 52r Sors: Morganus Kydwelly et Johannes Atwell Capellanus summoniti fuerunt ad respondendum Willelmo Cowedrey
msItem.explicit: 52r versus predictos Morganum et Johannem pro aliquibus dampnis occasione premissorum habitis et sustentis
msItem.note: The record is cited as Common Pleas, Michaelmas 10 Henry VII, rot. 342. Kydwelly was seated at Langton. A John Atwell (d. 1503?) was rector of Exeter College, Oxford; another (d. 1508) was a fellow of King's College, Cambridge. The chaplain sued Kydwelly's widow, Jane, between 1505 and 1515 (Selden Society 94: 325). Walter Atwell, the compiler of this manuscript, was presumably a close relation.

msItem.title: Copy of a subpoena concerning a riot, dated at Richmond 20 July
msItem.rubric: 52v By the Kyng
msItem.incipit: 52v ffor certaine grete Riottes and mysgouernaunces late by you commytted and doon in oure Countie of Norffolk contrary to oure lawes and peas

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the ague
msItem.rubric: 52v Magne
msItem.incipit: 52v Item take v sponfull of the wator of seynt joniswort and ij sponfull and do of aqua vite and put to geder and sett þe pacient when þe ague is vpon hym drynke som of hit at oon tyme and oon at anoþer tyme and hit shall hel hym ut patet p[er]wart?
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Mnemonic about diarrhea
msItem.rubric: 52v Cokkes
msItem.incipit: 52v Cruda lienteria simplexque diaria cum sanguine dissinteria / Stranguaria Guttate [...] per horas
msItem.note: Full transcription; the mnemonic is here attributed to John Cokkys (d. by 1475), physician and clerk of Oxford; added by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Prophecy
msItem.rubric: 52* recto Beda de dictis Merlini Silvestris
msItem.incipit: 52* recto In simplex domini quater Clx numeratis Reges anglorum non erunt de stirpe priorum
msItem.explicit: 52* recto Et rex britonum in adiutorium eius veniet et ipse preditorem deuvastabit qui gladio fratris sui peribit
msItem.note: Alongside the title of the work is written Jhesus mercye gramercy; this line and prophecy are added by by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Two medical recipes for an ese of laxe and suppositories; added by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for purging the humours
msItem.rubric: 52* rectoAd purgandum omnes humores et principaliter coleram secundum Magistrum Johannes Cokkes
msItem.note: The recipe is attributed to John Cokkys (d. by 1475), physician and clerk of Oxford; added by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Memorandum
msItem.incipit: 52* verso Memorandum that Magister Billyngton hath a good boke of pledyng of assise
msItem.note: Full transcription; Billyngton perhaps is George Billington of Strand Inn (sued for dues in 1503 and on subsequent occasions down to 1538, described in some actions as 'clerk') and of the Middle Temple (sued for dues 1528); Walter Atwell was also of Stand Inn; added by Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Latin saying or motto
msItem.incipit: 52* verso me saepe loqui penitant tacere numquam
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem attributed to John Skelton
msItem.incipit: 52* verso Qui trahis ex domiti ramum pede diue leonis
msItem.explicit: 52* verso Gens mortura sumus mortis ymago docet
msItem.note: The poem is ascribed to Skeltonidis laureati.

msItem.title: Law notes
msItem.note: Including two cases from the time of King Henry VII and a dictum by Fyneux C.J. (Fynyouz).

supportDesc.support:
Parchment (ff. 26, 27, 52*) and paper folded in folio. Folios 1-31, 32-52*: Hand with frilled cuff, surmounted by a six-petalled flower on a stalk ( 85 25 ) in the centre of the folio.
Folio 31bis: Unicorn ( 20 55 ) in the centre of the folio.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint (but also blind ruling), frame only. Single columns. 41-48 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: f. 1r contains a table of contents for year books that has been written in a neat cursive script with both Secretary and Anglicana features, possibly dating to the late 15th century.
ff. 1r-52* verso have been written largely in Walter Atwell's cursive hand with both Secretary and Anglicana features.
f. 31bis has been written in a later 16th-century cursive script with Secretary features.

provenance.p: A possible ownership inscription in the upper margin of f. 63r: Emanuel 1576.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.5.18, ff. 53r-[96a]

msItem.title: Reading in the Inner Temple, probably on Magna Carta 14
msItem.rubric: 53r Hic incipit le diversite enter court baron, hundred, tourne, del viconte, leete countie, et cessionz, et le diversite del power et le auctorite de chescun deux etc. Adeprimez il est appelle hundred quaunt est tenuz iii semayns de iii semayns
msItem.note: On f. 55r is a dictum per Malet en le sale et per tout le bank, referrring to the bench of the Inner Temple; for a detailed discussion of this text see Baker and Ringrose (1996), p. 211 [item 15].

msItem.title: Reading of William Huntley (d. before 1507), in the Inner Temple, Autumn 1499, on the Statute of Marlborough
msItem.finalRubric: 56r Huntley lectura prima Marlbrige capitulo viiio De sectis vero faciendis ad curiam magnatis etcaetera
msItem.note: The reading is of William Huntley (d. before 1507), in the Inner Temple, Autumn 1499 (see Selden Society 102: xxxviii, 174).

msItem.title: Anonymous reading on Westminster II, c. 13
msItem.rubric: 57rCapitulo xiii Westministerii secundi
msItem.incipit: 57r Sur cest estatute que comence Quia etiam viceocomes
msItem.note: Probably a Gray's Inn reading as suggested by the name Wangford (f. 46v), which is William Wangford (d. 1458), serjeant 1453, who also spoke at Spelman's reading (see ff. 41v-49v).

msItem.title: Anonymous reading on Westminster II, c. 12
msItem.rubric: 57rWestm. secundum capitulum xii
msItem.incipit: 58v Sur cest estatute que que comence Quia multi per maliciam
msItem.finalRubric: 58v Finis deo gracias quod Walterus Atwell

msItem.title: Anonymous reading on Westminster II, c. 9
msItem.rubric: 58vWestm. secundum capitulum ixm
msItem.incipit: 58v Sur cest estatute que comence Cum capitales domini

msItem.title: Notes on the commission of the peace
msItem.rubric: 60v De liver de Marow en le temple
msItem.finalRubric: 60v Ex en le lecture de Magistro Marowe cuius Anime propicius deus

msItem.title: Note on the Statute of Westminster II, c. 11
msItem.incipit: 60v Westmonasterium secundum capitulo xio

msItem.title: Reading of Thomas Marow (d. 1505) on Westminster I, c. 1, De pace, in the Inner Temple, Lent 1503, as a serjeant-elect
msItem.rubric: 62r Jhesus maria - Prima lectura de Magistro Marow - Westmonasterium primum capitulo primo
msItem.incipit: 62r De pace terre et ecclesie et conservatione eiusdem - Cest en affermative del comen ley et ne fuist fait pur ascun doute
msItem.finalRubric: 95r Finis laudetur deus quod Walterus Atwell cuius anime propicietur Deus amen Jhesus Jhesus Jhesus esto mihi Jhesus Amen

msItem.title: Anonymous reading on Westminster II, c. 8
msItem.rubric: 95r Westminsterium secundum capitulo viiio
msItem.incipit: 95r Sur cest estatute que commence Cum per plcatium motum

msItem.title: Anonymous reading on Westminster II, c. 23
msItem.rubric: 95v Westminsterium secundum capitulo xxiiio
msItem.incipit: 95v Sur [cest] estatut que comence Habeant de cetero executores
msItem.finalRubric: 96r Finis hujus capituli quod Walterus Atwell

msItem.title: A case of formedon form the year book 13 Richard II with a marginal reference to 9 Henry V
Law notes
msItem.note: The notes include case from the reign of Henry VII or Henry VIII (before 1519) in which Sr Rede and Sr Fynous speak; the chief justices are Rede C.J.C.P. 1506-1519 and Fyneux C.J.K.B. 1495-1525.

msItem.title: A reference to a lecture of Richard Hesketh
msItem.note: The reference is to a lecture de Magistro Askett in principio magni libri terminorum et annorum (also cited on f. i recto); The 'Great Book of Terms and Years' may be that from which the table survives at f. 1r.

msItem.title: Note on justifications of homicide
msItem.note: This note apparently relates to a case from the reign of King Henry VII described on ff. 96r-96v.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 53-96: Shield bearing three fleurs-de-lys surmounted by a crown and a four-petalled flower on a stalk, below the shield an initial T (?) ( 75 30 ) in the centre of the folio.

p.seg: Ruled in crayon (?), frame only. Single columns. 43-44 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a cursive script with both Secretary and Anglicana features.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant form of decoration.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.5.18, ff. 97r-101v

msItem.title: Readers' cases from the reading by Henry Tingleden (d. 1521) on the Statute of Gloucester, cc. 1-2, in Gray's Inn, Lent 1516
msItem.rubric: 99rAnno vii H. viii lectura Magistri [T] in quadragesima Glouc. capitulo primo
msItem.note: The identity of the reader is confirmed by the headline on f. 100v: anno vii H. viii. tempore quadragesime Tyngelden; and the margin of f. 99v:arg. in Greys In. For more information on this text, see Baker and Ringrose (1996), p. 213.

msItem.title: Cases on criminal law
msItem.rubric: 99v Westminsterium primum capitulo iio
msItem.incipit: 99v Argumentabilis casus. iiii ou vi homez alent a disseiser un home
msItem.note: From an unidentified reading in Gray's Inn on Westminster I, c. 2. For more information on this text, see Baker and Ringrose (1996), p. 213.

msItem.title: Cases from the reading by Humphrey Wingfield (d. 1545) on De conjunctim feoffatis in Gray's Inn, Lent 1517
msItem.rubric: 100r Lestatute conjunctim feoffatis Magistri Wynkfeld anno viii H. viii in quadragesima - Cases argumentabiles

msItem.title: Note (partially crossed out and faded)
msItem.note: Not read, but the note refers to xxij die anno xiij h. viij.

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.rubric: 101vIn hoc libro continentur tales lecture et annotationes sequentes
msItem.note: The table, which describes the whole volume, is written in the hand of Walter Atwell.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for consumption
msItem.rubric: 101vA meddecyn for a Consympcioun
msItem.incipit: 101v Acrens [?] dryed in pouder and putt hit in drynk it is good for a stych or a consumpcioun - vyneger and a lyttel quantite of hony sett in a sawcer and hett hit ouer þe fyer and put þerto a gall þat hath a pyth within of þe best and put þerto sum leves of rosys dryed and when it is warm washe your mouth þe gummys and spit owt it is good to void þe corrupcioun of þe hede per Cartlagg grocer
msItem.note: Full transcription.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 97-101: Plain-cuffed hand, on the palm the Greek letter alpha ( 90 30 ) in the centre of the folio.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 49-51 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant form of decoration.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.5.18, ff. 101a recto-101bis verso

msItem.title: A list of some cases in Sir Robert Brooke's Abridgement
msItem.rubric: 101a recto Broke - Peace
msItem.note: La Graunde Abridgement by Sir Robert Brooke (d. 1588) was first printed in 1573.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 101a-101bis: Jug with crown and quatrefoil ( 60 25 ) in the centre of the folio.

extent.seg: 1 leaf The leaf has been mounted vertically into te manuscript. Because its height exceeds the width of the manuscript, the leaf has been folded at the top, creating, what is now, f. 101bis.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a cursive script influenced by Humanistic minuscule.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant form of decoration.

origin.origDate: Copied in the last quarter of the 16th century.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
